chunks.original_text: 一致入真，体真应变。 万变不失吾真，是之谓神。 神之致谓之元，元之至谓之妙。 入元入妙，其实无得，复归本然。 非象非声，湛兮似或存，独立於元始元妙者，本有之性，非从外得。 元始以真妙观，元始以真妙听。 妙观见非象之象，妙听闻无声之声。 大象无形，无逃吾妙观。 太音希声，无逃吾妙听。 吾以妙为无极无上。 妙观无色，妙听无声，色声外尘，不能隔越。 六受用根，圆融涉入，故见无象之象，而非目闻，无声之声，而非耳尘， 销觉圆，妙观出於天地之外，妙听出於音声之表，故无所不见，无所不闻，是谓无极无上。 吾故无极无上真妙。 真妙真元，真元不可元。 真妙真神，真神不可神。 真妙真真，真真不可真。 真妙真道，真道不可道。 真妙极矣。 此言体妙者，与元真神道者不同，既得真妙，则元为妙元真元不可元，神为妙神真神不可神，真为妙真真真不可真，道为妙道真道不可道。 由元始而下，虽共此五名，而所得妙力，各有差殊，唯以妙极为至。 故曰：真妙极矣。 第二章一百四十六言 真妙太上，太上真妙。 道极不可名，寄之曰真妙。 尊极不可名，寄之曰太上。 妙极而上，故曰真妙。 太上上极而妙，故曰太上真妙。 妙生元，元生神，神生真，真生道，道生德，德生徼，徼生妙，妙生无，无生有，有则有，无则无，有无相生，阴阳相推，太化变易。 妙之降曰元，元之降曰神，神之降曰真，真之降曰道，道之降曰德，德之降曰徼。 徼者小道也。 众人自道降为德，德降为徼，徼入於有，一入於有，与道益离。 真人自徼返入於妙，　自妙入无，自无出有，欲建立则以无为有，欲寂静则以有为无。 欲有则生，天地不为多，欲无则返，太虚不为少。 以有以无，出阳入阴，相生相推，如太化之变易。 妙无体也。 有有无无，无无有有，吾居徼妙之常。 真人以妙无为体，以妙有为用。 湛然常住，无之体也。 应变不穷，有之用也。 有有之用生於无无之体，无无之体出为有有之用。 以有为徼，以无为妙，故曰吾居徼妙之常。 老子曰：常无欲以观其妙，常有欲以观其徼。 此两者同。 出而异名，同谓之玄。 世人体无则不能有，体有则不能无，观妙则不能徼，观徼则不能妙，是皆囿於形器，不能出入於有无之间。 真人以妙无为体，出而有，虽小道不为，不足入而无，虽体妙不为有余，盖以有无徼妙为常。 如此则徼即妙，妙即徼，有即无，无即有。 故曰：出而异名，同谓之玄。 徼妙之常曰道。 道之常曰真。 真之常曰神。 神之常曰元。 元之常曰妙。 妙之常曰吾。 居无极矣。 元妙之妙，不变不异，故曰常。 徼者有也，妙者无也，有亦无，无亦有，乃为徼妙之常。 徼妙之常，然后为道。 道之常曰真。 真之常曰神。 神之常曰元。 元之常曰妙。 妙之常曰吾。 所以自居常者，无始无终之谓也。 不可视，不可听，不可搏，不可有，不可无，不可元，不可神，不可真，不可道，入乎无上，同乎无极，是为真妙矣。 世人以物求道者，欲其可视、可听、可搏、可有、可无。 以理求道者，欲其可元、可神、可真、可道。 使道而可以视、听、有、无求之，则道为物矣。 使道而可以元、真、神、道名之，则道为理矣。 真人外不役物，内不着理，故非视而见，非听而闻，非搏而坚，非有而在，非无而居，非元而元，非神而神，非真而真，非道而道，入乎无上，同乎无极，皆不可名，故曰真妙。
chunks.translated_text:
Unity enters authenticity; embodying authenticity, it responds to change. Though myriad transformations arise, none lose my authenticity—this is called Spirit. The culmination of Spirit is called Origin; the attainment of Origin is called Mystery. Entering Origin, entering Mystery, in truth nothing is gained—only a return to the original state.

Neither form nor sound, abiding in stillness as if existing yet not, standing alone in the Primordial Origin and Primordial Mystery—this is the inherent nature, not obtained from without. The Primordial Origin observes with true Mystery; the Primordial Origin listens with true Mystery. The wondrous gaze sees the formless form; the wondrous hearing perceives the soundless sound. The great image has no shape, yet nothing escapes my wondrous gaze. The supreme tone is soundless, yet nothing escapes my wondrous hearing. I take Mystery as the boundless and supreme.

The wondrous gaze is without color; the wondrous hearing is without sound. Beyond color and sound, external dust cannot obstruct. The six sense faculties interpenetrate and merge, thus seeing the formless form yet not through the eyes, hearing the soundless sound yet not through the ears. Perception dissolves into perfect clarity. The wondrous gaze transcends heaven and earth; the wondrous hearing surpasses sound and voice. Thus nothing is unseen, nothing unheard—this is called the boundless and supreme. Therefore, I am the boundless and supreme true Mystery.

True Mystery, true Origin—true Origin cannot be Origin. True Mystery, true Spirit—true Spirit cannot be Spirit. True Mystery, true Authenticity—true Authenticity cannot be Authenticity. True Mystery, true Dao—true Dao cannot be Dao. True Mystery is ultimate.

This speaks of embodying Mystery, distinct from those who embody Origin, Authenticity, Spirit, or Dao. Having attained true Mystery, then Origin becomes wondrous Origin—true Origin cannot be Origin; Spirit becomes wondrous Spirit—true Spirit cannot be Spirit; Authenticity becomes wondrous Authenticity—true Authenticity cannot be Authenticity; Dao becomes wondrous Dao—true Dao cannot be Dao. From the Primordial Origin downward, though all share these five names, the wondrous power attained differs in each, with Mystery alone as the ultimate. Thus it is said: True Mystery is ultimate.

**Chapter Two, One Hundred Forty-Six Characters**

True Mystery is the Supreme; the Supreme is true Mystery. The ultimate of Dao cannot be named—it is provisionally called true Mystery. The ultimate of honor cannot be named—it is provisionally called the Supreme. Mystery is ultimate and beyond, thus called true Mystery. The Supreme is ultimate and transcendent, thus called the Supreme true Mystery.

Mystery gives rise to Origin; Origin gives rise to Spirit; Spirit gives rise to Authenticity; Authenticity gives rise to Dao; Dao gives rise to virtue; virtue gives rise to subtlety; subtlety gives rise to Mystery; Mystery gives rise to Non-being; Non-being gives rise to Being. Being is Being; Non-being is Non-being. Being and Non-being generate each other; yin and yang mutually transform—great transformation and change.

The descent of Mystery is called Origin; the descent of Origin is called Spirit; the descent of Spirit is called Authenticity; the descent of Authenticity is called Dao; the descent of Dao is called virtue; the descent of virtue is called subtlety. Subtlety is the lesser Dao. The multitude descend from Dao to virtue, from virtue to subtlety, and enter into Being. Once entering Being, they drift ever farther from the Dao. The perfected person ascends from subtlety back to Mystery, from Mystery into Non-being, from Non-being into Being—desiring to establish, they take Non-being as Being; desiring stillness, they take Being as Non-being. Desiring Being, it arises—heaven and earth do not make it more; desiring Non-being, it returns—Great Emptiness does not make it less. Through Being and Non-being, emerging in yang and entering yin, mutually generating and transforming, like the great changes of transformation.

Mystery has no form. Being has Non-being; Non-being has Being. I dwell in the constancy of subtlety and Mystery. The perfected person takes wondrous Non-being as essence and wondrous Being as function. Abiding in stillness is the essence of Non-being; responding endlessly to change is the function of Being. The function of Being arises from the essence of Non-being; the essence of Non-being manifests as the function of Being. Taking Being as subtlety and Non-being as Mystery, thus it is said: I dwell in the constancy of subtlety and Mystery.

Laozi said: "Constantly without desire, observe its Mystery; constantly with desire, observe its subtlety." These two emerge differently yet are called the same—profound. The worldly, embodying Non-being, cannot grasp Being; embodying Being, cannot grasp Non-being. Observing Mystery, they cannot perceive subtlety; observing subtlety, they cannot perceive Mystery. All are confined by forms and instruments, unable to enter and exit between Being and Non-being. The perfected person takes wondrous Non-being as essence, emerging into Being. Though the lesser Dao is not pursued, it is not insufficient to enter Non-being; though embodying Mystery, it is not excessive. For they take Being and Non-being, subtlety and Mystery as constant. Thus subtlety is Mystery; Mystery is subtlety; Being is Non-being; Non-being is Being. Therefore it is said: "Emerging differently, they are called the same—profound."

The constancy of subtlety and Mystery is called Dao. The constancy of Dao is called Authenticity. The constancy of Authenticity is called Spirit. The constancy of Spirit is called Origin. The constancy of Origin is called Mystery. The constancy of Mystery is called I. Dwelling in the boundless.

The Mystery of Origin-Mystery is unchanging and unaltered—thus called constant. Subtlety is Being; Mystery is Non-being. Being is also Non-being; Non-being is also Being—this is the constancy of subtlety and Mystery. The constancy of subtlety and Mystery is then Dao. The constancy of Dao is Authenticity. The constancy of Authenticity is Spirit. The constancy of Spirit is Origin. The constancy of Origin is Mystery. The constancy of Mystery is I. Thus abiding in constancy is called without beginning or end.

It cannot be seen, cannot be heard, cannot be grasped, cannot be possessed, cannot be Origin, cannot be Spirit, cannot be Authenticity, cannot be Dao. Entering the supreme, merging with the boundless—this is true Mystery. The worldly seek Dao through things, desiring it to be seen, heard, grasped, possessed, or not possessed. Those who seek Dao through principle desire it to be Origin, Spirit, Authenticity, or Dao. If Dao could be sought through seeing, hearing, Being, or Non-being, then Dao would be a thing. If Dao could be named as Origin, Authenticity, Spirit, or Dao, then Dao would be principle. The perfected person is not enslaved by things externally nor attached to principle internally. Thus without seeing, they see; without hearing, they hear; without grasping, they hold firm; without Being, they exist; without Non-being, they abide; without Origin, they are Origin; without Spirit, they are Spirit; without Authenticity, they are Authenticity; without Dao, they are Dao. Entering the supreme, merging with the boundless—all cannot be named, thus called true Mystery.

Virtue is the dispersion of nature into affairs, unstable. Thus virtue may be lost, but the Dao is never lost. If virtue is lost, it returns to the Dao—there is no Dao apart from this.

The Dao resides between life and death, gain and loss, never not one. If one chases the changes of life and death, follows the names of gain and loss, it disperses into virtue. But if one knows it emerges from the Dao and gathers into oneness, then virtue is the Dao, and the Dao and virtue are one.

chunks.original_text: 第三章一百六言 真妙非声非象，实非声象，其上不皦，其下不昧。 妙非形色声听，由人不能，於元始之初，体元入妙，吸集尘象，收揽成根。 耳目鼻舌，及与身意分一精明，内意纷纭，外根互运，坚温暖动驱役，四大六根。 四大更接，外尘转迷，本始若能，了形相空，格去外尘，使色香味触各不绿根。 见色如与盲等，嗅香如与风等，尝味如与蜡等，见触如与空等，外尘既销，则六受用根，顿然清净，净极妙敷，非象非声，见闻觉知出於根外，故极其上至大而不皦，极其下至微而不昧。 恍兮惚兮，杳杳冥冥，真妙妙真，视不见，听不闻。 物物自有元始，不可见，不可闻。 恍惚杳冥，而非无也。 故佛书云：若以色见我，以音声求我，是人行邪道，不能见如来。 道书云：视不可见，听不可闻，离种种边，名为妙道。 所谓道者，若从外入，即物非道。 人所以不能知道者，盖贪色逐声，为物所转使。 吾元始之妙，所谓不可见，不可闻者，迷为可见，可闻，转离本始。 楞严佛问阿难言：今汝细观，从日月宫至七金山，云腾鸟飞，风动尘起，远近诸物，虽复差殊，同汝见精，清净所瞩。 若见是物，汝亦可见吾之见。 若以同见，名为见吾，则吾不见。 时何不见，吾不见之。 处若不见，吾不见之。 地则自然非物，云何非汝。 若汝见时，是汝非我，见性周遍，非汝而谁。 由是观之，入之见色，唯我独知彼。 彼自知各见其独，无同见者，如是则我之所见，彼不能见。 我之所闻，彼不能闻。 若以同闻，名为我闻，则我不闻。 时彼应合，知彼既不知，则彼之所闻，非我闻也。 味触觉知义亦如是。 庄周所谓见独者其亦是欤。 元始於太妙，寂兮寥兮，绳绳兮，湛然不可名。 凡可以名，皆属名数，是二非一。 唯不可名，然后为道。 且道之近体，莫过於无，莫过於空，然无即与有对，空即与实对，皆堕名数，是二非一。 唯不可名，然后为一。 所谓一者，是无非无，是有非有，是空非空，是实非实，以至离无，离有，离空，离实，即无，即有，即空，即实，是离，非离，是即，非即，及其至也。 即离俱非，名不可得，方为妙道。 寂寥者，无也。 绳绳者，永也。 既无矣，绳绳然而不可无，虽不可无，然寂寥兮不可有，是谓无名。 元妙，神妙，真妙，道妙，天地虚妙，阴阳同妙，日月合妙，五行含妙，八卦杂妙，万物尽妙。 物非道不成，真非道不立。 故元得妙而元，神得妙风神，真得妙而真，道得妙而道。 此所谓真非道不立。 天地得妙而成，阴阳得妙而分，日月得妙而明，五行得妙而相克相生，八卦得妙而相推相荡，万物杂妙而以死以生，故曰物非道不成。 至虚至静，吾曰虚静。 妙始非妙，不可得矣。 妙体吾元始。 至虚极守静。 万虚之极，於有无不虚。 静之极，於动无不静。 若吾曰虚静，即有虚静之心。 通有则不得虚，遇动即不得静。 妙始非妙，妙不可得，惟体吾元始。 知有无不虚，知动无不静，是谓元始之道。 第四章六十四言 孰以元元，孰以神神，孰以真真，孰以道道，孰以名名。 吾强曰：妙入吾妙矣。 知元守元，元始不元。 知神守神，神始不神。 知真守真，真始不真。 知道守道，道始不道。 知知守知，即为住着。
chunks.translated_text:
**Chapter Three: One Hundred and Six Sayings**

True Mystery is neither sound nor form, yet truly neither sound nor form. Above, it is not bright; below, it is not dim. Mystery is not shape, color, sound, or hearing—yet humans cannot fathom it. In the primordial beginning, embodying the Origin and entering Mystery, they gather dust-like forms and draw them in to form roots. Ears, eyes, nose, tongue, body, and mind divide the single essence of clarity. Inner thoughts scatter; outer senses interact. Hardness, warmth, movement, and activity drive the Four Great Elements and the six senses. As the Four Great Elements shift and connect, external dust turns delusive. If one could grasp the primordial beginning, realizing form and appearance as empty, and sever external dust, then color, fragrance, flavor, and touch would no longer cling to the roots. Seeing color would be as if blind; smelling fragrance, as if wind; tasting flavor, as if wax; feeling touch, as if empty. Once external dust dissolves, the six sense organs suddenly become pure. At the extreme of purity, Mystery unfolds—neither form nor sound. Seeing, hearing, awareness, and knowing arise beyond the senses. Thus, at its utmost height, it is vast yet not bright; at its utmost depth, it is subtle yet not dim. Vague and indistinct, obscure and profound—true Mystery, mysterious truth. Seeing yet not seeing, hearing yet not hearing. Each thing has its primordial beginning, unseen and unheard. Vague and obscure, yet not nothing.

Thus, the Buddhist scriptures say: *"If one sees me in form or seeks me in sound, that person walks the deviant path and cannot see the Tathāgata."* The Daoist texts say: *"That which cannot be seen, cannot be heard—transcending all extremes—is called the Mysterious Dao."* What is called Dao, if sought from without, is but a thing and not Dao. Why can humans not know Dao? Because they covet color and chase sound, turned by things. The primordial Mystery of the Origin—what is called unseen and unheard—when deluded, becomes seen and heard, turning away from the Origin.

In the *Śūraṅgama Sūtra*, the Buddha asked Ānanda: *"Now observe carefully: from the palaces of the sun and moon to the Seven Golden Mountains, clouds rising, birds flying, wind stirring dust—all things near and far, though differing, are seen by your pure vision. If what you see are things, then you also see my seeing. If seeing the same is called seeing me, then I do not see. Why do you not see what I do not see? Where I do not see, you do not see. If the place is unseen, then it is naturally not a thing—how is it not yours? When you see, it is you, not me. The nature of seeing pervades all—who else but you? Thus, entering to see form, only I alone know it. Each knows their own seeing uniquely; none share the same vision. Therefore, what I see, others cannot see; what I hear, others cannot hear. If hearing the same is called hearing me, then I do not hear. Then they should know—since they do not know, what they hear is not what I hear."* Taste, touch, and awareness are likewise. As Zhuang Zhou said of *"seeing the unique"*—is this not it?

The Origin in the Great Mystery—still and silent, boundless and profound, serene and unnameable. All that can be named belongs to names and numbers—duality, not unity. Only the unnameable is Dao. As for Dao’s nearness to form, nothing surpasses Non-being, nothing surpasses Emptiness. Yet Non-being opposes Being, Emptiness opposes Substance—both fall into names and numbers, duality, not unity. Only the unnameable is One. What is called One is Non-being yet not Non-being, Being yet not Being, Emptiness yet not Emptiness, Substance yet not Substance. To the point of transcending Non-being, Being, Emptiness, and Substance—neither Non-being nor Being, neither Emptiness nor Substance—transcending yet not transcending, identical yet not identical. At its utmost, neither identity nor transcendence can be named—only then is it the Mysterious Dao.

Stillness is Non-being; boundlessness is eternity. Though Non-being, it is inexhaustibly so; though inexhaustible, still and silent, it cannot be possessed—this is called the Unnameable. Primordial Mystery, Spiritual Mystery, True Mystery, Dao Mystery; the emptiness of Heaven and Earth, the shared Mystery of yin and yang, the united Mystery of sun and moon, the contained Mystery of the Five Phases, the blended Mystery of the Eight Trigrams, the all-pervading Mystery of the myriad things. Things are not completed without Dao; truth is not established without Dao. Thus, the Origin attains Mystery and is Origin; Spirit attains Mystery and is Spirit; Truth attains Mystery and is Truth; Dao attains Mystery and is Dao—this is what is meant by *"truth is not established without Dao."* Heaven and Earth attain Mystery and are formed; yin and yang attain Mystery and divide; sun and moon attain Mystery and shine; the Five Phases attain Mystery and mutually overcome and generate; the Eight Trigrams attain Mystery and mutually propel and agitate; the myriad things attain blended Mystery and live and die. Thus, *"things are not completed without Dao."*

Utterly empty, utterly still—I call it emptiness and stillness. The Mysterious Beginning is not Mystery—it cannot be grasped. The Mysterious Body is my Origin. Utter emptiness, extreme stillness. The utmost of emptiness does not empty Being and Non-being; the utmost of stillness does not still movement. If I say emptiness and stillness, then there is a mind for emptiness and stillness. Encountering Being, it is not empty; encountering movement, it is not still. The Mysterious Beginning is not Mystery—Mystery cannot be grasped. Only by embodying my Origin, knowing that Being and Non-being are not empty, knowing that movement is not unstilled—this is the Dao of the Origin.

**Chapter Four: Sixty-Four Sayings**

Who attains the Origin through the Origin? Who attains Spirit through Spirit? Who attains Truth through Truth? Who attains Dao through Dao? Who attains names through names? I boldly say: Mystery enters my Mystery. Knowing the Origin and guarding the Origin, the Origin is no longer Origin. Knowing Spirit and guarding Spirit, Spirit is no longer Spirit. Knowing Truth and guarding Truth, Truth is no longer Truth. Knowing Dao and guarding Dao, Dao is no longer Dao. Knowing knowledge and guarding knowledge—this is attachment.

chunks.original_text: 知知无知，然后六通。 四辟在元，非元在神，非神在真，非真在道。 非道有名，非名强名，曰：妙若徼若，妙入吾妙矣。 然后合为元，散为神，致一为真，万变为道。 升清降浊，布列精魂，变化之道，穷象极形，复归乎妙。 元始以妙为体，故元乃妙之合，神乃妙之散，真乃妙之一，道乃妙之变。 下至於分阴分阳，降浊升清，布列精魂，万物以成，皆由妙出。 始出於妙，极其变化，草木昆虫，水火土木，穷象极形，皆吾妙也。 物自顺以生，道自返而成。 人能自象形而返之，皆能至妙。 第五章九十八言 吾始乎妙，万灵不神，万法不名，万境不生。 非不神，妙灵无照。 非不名，妙法无因。 非不生，妙境无缘。 妙妙无对，是谓独立。 妙神无灵何以故，神无方故。 妙法无名何以故，法无法故。 妙境无有何以故，无所缘故。 元始之妙，湛寂自照，无照照者，无法无名，离诸起灭，因相不生，因既不生，缘无所偶，故诸尘象无得而成，纯以妙明，妙妙无对，是谓独立。 不子不孙，同乎无独。 出入绵绵，同乎无门。 万物归元，不见其元宰。 非子非孙，其传无尽，故无独。 出入绵绵，不知其际，故无门。 虽主万物，万物归焉，而莫见其所以主之者。 吾始於妙，寂兮，寥兮，绳绳兮，湛然兮，廓然兮，吾不知其生。 故曰：长生之道。 有生则有灭，唯无生然后为长生。 元始之妙，非由生而生，故吾不知其生。 但见寂寥兮，其静也。 绳绳兮，其长也。 湛然兮，其存也。 廓然兮，其广也。 故命之曰：长生之道。 第六章一百六十言 自然非妙，妙非自然，吾元始於妙。 其上不皦，恍兮惚，其下不昧，惚兮恍，恍惚混蒙，上下同妙，妙恍妙惚，非象非物。 自然者可以名道，而道非自然，何以故。 自然有定体，而道无定体，若以道为自然，则道不当降而生物。 以物为自然，则物不当变而成道。 故曰：自然非妙，妙非自然。 元始之妙，居於有无之间。 恍者明也有也，惚者灭也无也。 至妙之极其大不见其皦，既出而有，又寂而无，故曰恍兮惚。 极其小不见其昧，既居其无，又出而有，故曰惚兮恍。 恍惚混蒙，出入於有无之间，与上下皆同於妙，故曰妙恍妙惚，非象非物。 吾始元元，妙惚妙恍，非物非象。 吾始神神，杳杳冥冥，非妙非形。 吾始真真，冥冥杳杳，非形非妙。 吾始道道，精中有真，自然之道。 元、神、真三者，是妙之分，未尽妙体，然皆非物非象，在恍惚杳冥之间。 至於道则始有精，始有真，非杳非冥，非恍非惚，然犹未离自然也。 自道而降，精散而为形，真降而为物，物生而道之自然又丧矣。 道法自然，自然真道，真者自然之号，五口不知其自然。 自然为真，真者自然之道。 故曰道法自然。 所谓道之自然，与物之自然，名同义异。 世所谓自然者，乃不变之称，方其迷乱无智，执物之有，以为自然，未能甄明自然本体，则其自然深可障道，圣人辟之。 此首章所以言自然非妙，妙非自然，盖此意也。 所谓道之自然，道降而为物，其自不变此道之自然者也。 世所谓自然，皆物之自，如鹄白乌玄世，既无知以玄白为乌鹄之自，不知鹄之所以白，乌之所以玄。 又有使之然者，亦非自也。 由世以非自为自，非然为然，故圣人讳之。
chunks.translated_text:
Knowing knowledge as no-knowledge—only then are the six penetrations achieved. The four unfoldings reside in Origin; it is not that Origin resides in Spirit, nor that Spirit resides in Truth, nor that Truth resides in Dao. Dao is not named; names are not forced—this is called: subtly as the elusive, subtly entering my subtlety. Only then is it united as Origin, dispersed as Spirit, concentrated as One into Truth, transformed myriadly as Dao. Rising with the pure and descending with the turbid, arraying essence and soul, the Dao of transformation exhausts images and extremes of form, returning to subtlety. Origin takes subtlety as its body; thus Origin is the union of subtlety, Spirit is the dispersion of subtlety, Truth is the oneness of subtlety, and Dao is the transformation of subtlety. Down to the division of yin and yang, the descent of the turbid and ascent of the pure, the arraying of essence and soul—all things are completed, all issuing from subtlety. First emerging from subtlety, exhausting its transformations, grasses and trees, insects, water and fire, earth and wood—exhausting images and extremes of form—all are my subtlety. Things spontaneously follow to be born; Dao spontaneously returns to be completed. If one can return from images and forms to their source, all can attain subtlety.

**Chapter Five: Ninety-Eight Sayings**

I begin with subtlety—myriad spirits are not spirit, myriad dharmas are not named, myriad realms are not born. Not that they are not spirit—subtle spirit has no illumination. Not that they are not named—subtle dharma has no cause. Not that they are not born—subtle realm has no condition. Subtlety upon subtlety has no opposite—this is called independence. Why is subtle spirit without spirit? Because spirit has no direction. Why is subtle dharma without name? Because dharma has no dharma. Why is subtle realm without existence? Because it has no condition. The subtlety of the Origin is profoundly still and self-illuminating; without illumination, there is no illuminator, no dharma, no name. Detached from all arising and ceasing, causes do not produce effects; since causes do not produce, conditions have no counterpart. Thus all dusts and images cannot be completed—purely through subtle clarity. Subtlety upon subtlety has no opposite—this is called independence. Neither child nor grandchild, it is one with non-solitude. Flowing in and out endlessly, it is one with no gate. Myriad things return to Origin, yet its governance is unseen. Neither child nor grandchild, its transmission is inexhaustible—thus it is not solitary. Flowing in and out endlessly, its bounds are unknown—thus it has no gate. Though it governs myriad things, and myriad things return to it, none see how it governs. I begin with subtlety—still, vast, continuous, profound, expansive—I know not its arising. Thus it is called: the Dao of long life. Where there is birth, there is death; only where there is no birth is there long life. The subtlety of the Origin does not arise from arising—thus I know not its arising. Only stillness is seen as vast, continuity as enduring, profundity as abiding, expansiveness as boundless. Thus it is named: the Dao of long life.

**Chapter Six: One Hundred and Sixty Sayings**

The spontaneous is not subtlety; subtlety is not the spontaneous—I originate from subtlety. Above, it is not bright—dimly, vaguely; below, it is not dark—vaguely, dimly. Dim and vague, obscure and indistinct, above and below are one in subtlety. Subtle dimness, subtle vagueness—neither image nor thing. The spontaneous can be named Dao, yet Dao is not the spontaneous. Why? The spontaneous has a fixed body, while Dao has no fixed body. If Dao were taken as the spontaneous, then Dao should not descend to generate things. If things were taken as the spontaneous, then things should not transform to become Dao. Thus it is said: the spontaneous is not subtlety; subtlety is not the spontaneous. The subtlety of the Origin dwells between being and non-being. Dimness is brightness, being; vagueness is extinction, non-being. At the extreme of subtlety, its greatness is not seen as bright—having emerged into being, yet still and non-being—thus it is called dimly, vaguely. At its smallest, its darkness is not seen—dwelling in non-being, yet emerging into being—thus it is called vaguely, dimly. Dim and vague, obscure and indistinct, emerging and entering between being and non-being, above and below alike in subtlety—thus it is called subtle dimness, subtle vagueness, neither image nor thing. I begin with Origin—subtly vague, subtly dim, neither thing nor image. I begin with Spirit—profoundly obscure, profoundly dark, neither subtlety nor form. I begin with Truth—darkly obscure, obscurely profound, neither form nor subtlety. I begin with Dao—essence contains truth, the spontaneous Dao. Origin, Spirit, and Truth are divisions of subtlety, yet do not exhaust its body—all are neither thing nor image, dwelling between dimness, vagueness, obscurity, and darkness. As for Dao, only then is there essence, only then is there truth—neither obscure nor dark, neither dim nor vague—yet still not detached from the spontaneous. Descending from Dao, essence disperses into form, truth descends into things—things arise, and Dao’s spontaneity is lost. Dao follows the spontaneous; the spontaneous is the true Dao. "True" is the designation of the spontaneous. The five mouths know not its spontaneity. The spontaneous is true; truth is the Dao of the spontaneous. Thus it is said: Dao follows the spontaneous. The so-called spontaneity of Dao and the spontaneity of things share the same name but differ in meaning. What the world calls spontaneous is a term for non-change. When deluded and without wisdom, clinging to the existence of things as spontaneous, failing to discern the original body of the spontaneous—then this spontaneity deeply obstructs Dao, and the sage rejects it. This is the intent behind the opening lines: the spontaneous is not subtlety; subtlety is not the spontaneous. The so-called spontaneity of Dao is that when Dao descends to become things, its self remains unchanging—this is the spontaneity of Dao. What the world calls spontaneous is the self of things, such as the whiteness of swans or the blackness of crows. Lacking knowledge, they take black and white as the self of crows and swans, not knowing why swans are white or crows are black. There is also that which makes them so—this is not self. Since the world takes the non-self as self and the non-so as so, the sage avoids such terms.

Knowing Truth and guarding Truth, Truth is no longer Truth. Knowing Dao and guarding Dao, Dao is no longer Dao. Knowing knowledge and guarding knowledge—this is attachment.

chunks.original_text: 虽然圣人达道之权，知自然性，至於论道，尚谓吾不知其自然，盖谓有知之之心，则是使之自然，非自然矣。 而况欲以世之情解妄想卜度者哉。 真法神，神法元、元法妙。 妙无法，故妙为万法之宗。 无法法，无元元，无神神，无真真，无道道，无无无，无有有。 吾之至妙，入元始之妙。 苟有所法，则有所未至，故真不免法神，神不免法元，元不免法妙。 至妙而后无法。 惟其无法，故为万物之宗。 如是则无法，无元，无神，无真，无道，无无，无有。 惟体妙者能之，故《释氏传》法句曰：法本法无法，无法法亦法，今付无法时，法法何曾法。 第七章一百二十言 至妙无间，无始，无极，无尽，无际，无央。 无间无无间，无始无无始，无极无无极，无尽无无尽，无际无无际，无央无无央。 无间不见，其断也。 无始不见，其先也。 无极不见，其上也。 无尽不见，其终也。 无际不见，其边也。 无央不见，其广也。 虽无间断续，不足以名道，故亦无无间。 虽无始先后，不足以名道，故亦无无始。 虽无极上下，不足以名道，故亦无无极。 虽无尽始终，不足以名道，故亦无无尽。 虽无际边中，不足以名道，故亦无无际。 虽无央广狭，不足以名道，故亦无无央。 殚世之言语，不足以名道，故大道无名。 吾始无央，有无一体。 吾始无际，混合太微。 天地六合，巨细一妙。 妙游巨细，孰观其体。 所谓无央者，不独空空无际也，必有无同体，虚实共贯，然后为无央。 所谓无际者，不独极其广大也，必混合太微，巨细如一，然后为无际。 如是则大而天地，广而六合，巨而虚空，细而微尘，皆为一妙。 故妙游出入天地，偃息微尘，周行虚空，举持六合，孰知其体，孰穷其妙。 吾曰无形，无声，无名。 吾始妙，中妙，三无之妙。 吾元始至道，是谓极乐。 妙游含容之器，与天地万物为终，然极而不尽。 以不形形故无形，以不声声故无声，以不名名故无名。 妙无次第而入，妙有次第，故有始妙，有中妙，妙之极为三无之妙。 是为元始至道极乐。 妙游无所不包，无所不含，与天地万物为终。 而妙无终，故曰极而不尽。 第八章四十四言 妙与天地万物为终，尽吾无终。 妙与天地万物为元，始吾无始。 德游其中，天地万物不可观焉。 德游至妙，与物还矣。 妙与物为终，而妙无终。 妙与物为始，而妙无始。 妙游於物中，物不得而知焉。 故曰：德游者以物而言也。 真人体妙而游於物，则为妙游。 物得妙而妙在物中，为德游。 物有壤而妙无壤，故曰与物还矣。 第九章四十二言 妙游无碍，元游无知，神游无方，真游无变，道游无体，德游无名，物游无间。 是谓与物同游，出生入死之道尽矣。 妙、元、神、真、道，此五者，道之名。 而有游於此五者，方名为道。 道者，吾之本真，谓之元始之始。 游於妙为无碍，游於元为无知，游於神为无方，游於真为无变，游於道为无体。 又降而游於德，不可以德名。 细而游於物，不可以物间。 精而与妙同游，不可得而见。 粗而与物同游，不可得而隐。 此至人所以出生入死，而以生死为旦暮之常者此也。 元始说先天道德经注解卷之一竟 元始说先天道德经注解卷之二
chunks.translated_text:
Though the sage has mastered the subtleties of Dao and understands the nature of spontaneity, when discoursing on Dao, they still say, "I do not know its spontaneity." For to claim knowledge of it is to impose spontaneity upon it—this is no longer spontaneity. How much less can those who rely on worldly sentiments, deluded thoughts, and speculative conjectures fathom it?

The true follows the numinous, the numinous follows the origin, the origin follows the subtle. The subtle has no method, and thus it is the source of the myriad methods. Without method as method, without origin as origin, without numinous as numinous, without true as true, without Dao as Dao, without nothingness as nothingness, without being as being—this is my utmost subtlety, entering the subtlety of the primordial origin. If there is something to follow, then there is something not yet attained. Thus, the true cannot but follow the numinous, the numinous cannot but follow the origin, and the origin cannot but follow the subtle. Only when one reaches the utmost subtlety is there no method to follow. Precisely because it has no method, it is the source of the myriad things. As such, there is no method, no origin, no numinous, no true, no Dao, no nothingness, no being. Only those who embody subtlety can attain this. Thus, the *Dharmapada* of the *Śākya Transmission* states:

*The Dharma is originally Dharma without Dharma,
Without Dharma, Dharma is still Dharma.
Now, when no-Dharma is transmitted,
What Dharma has ever been Dharma?*

**Chapter Seven, One Hundred and Twenty Characters**

The utmost subtlety is without interval, without beginning, without limit, without end, without bounds, without center.
Without interval yet not without interval, without beginning yet not without beginning, without limit yet not without limit, without end yet not without end, without bounds yet not without bounds, without center yet not without center.
Without interval—one does not see its severance.
Without beginning—one does not see its precedence.
Without limit—one does not see its above.
Without end—one does not see its conclusion.
Without bounds—one does not see its edge.
Without center—one does not see its expanse.

Though without interval, continuity and discontinuity are insufficient to name Dao, thus there is also no "without interval."
Though without beginning, before and after are insufficient to name Dao, thus there is also no "without beginning."
Though without limit, above and below are insufficient to name Dao, thus there is also no "without limit."
Though without end, beginning and end are insufficient to name Dao, thus there is also no "without end."
Though without bounds, edge and center are insufficient to name Dao, thus there is also no "without bounds."
Though without center, expanse and narrowness are insufficient to name Dao, thus there is also no "without center."
Exhausting all the world’s words is still insufficient to name Dao, thus the Great Dao is nameless.

My beginning is without center—being and nothingness are one body.
My beginning is without bounds—it merges with the primordial subtle.
Heaven and earth, the six directions—great and small are one subtlety.
The subtle roams through great and small—who can perceive its essence?

The so-called "without center" is not merely emptiness without bounds; it must have being and nothingness as one body, void and full mutually pervading—only then is it without center.
The so-called "without bounds" is not merely boundless vastness; it must merge with the primordial subtle, great and small as one—only then is it without bounds.
Thus, vast as heaven and earth, expansive as the six directions, immense as the void, minute as a speck of dust—all are one subtlety. Therefore, the subtle roams in and out of heaven and earth, rests within a speck of dust, circulates through the void, upholds the six directions—who knows its essence, who exhausts its subtlety?

I say: without form, without sound, without name.
My beginning is subtle, my middle is subtle—the subtlety of the three nones.
My primordial origin is the utmost Dao—this is called ultimate bliss.
The vessel of subtle roaming contains and embraces, accompanying heaven, earth, and the myriad things to their end, yet it is inexhaustible in its extremity.
Because it does not take form as form, it is without form; because it does not take sound as sound, it is without sound; because it does not take name as name, it is without name.
The subtle enters without sequence, yet the subtle has sequence—thus there is the subtlety of the beginning, the subtlety of the middle, and the utmost subtlety of the three nones. This is the primordial origin, the utmost Dao, ultimate bliss.
The subtle roaming is all-embracing, all-containing, accompanying heaven, earth, and the myriad things to their end. Yet the subtle has no end, thus it is said to be inexhaustible in its extremity.

**Chapter Eight, Forty-Four Characters**

The subtle accompanies heaven, earth, and the myriad things to their end—yet my end is without end.
The subtle accompanies heaven, earth, and the myriad things to their origin—yet my origin is without origin.
Virtue roams within it—heaven, earth, and the myriad things cannot be perceived.
Virtue roams in the utmost subtlety and returns with things.
The subtle accompanies things to their end, yet the subtle has no end.
The subtle accompanies things to their origin, yet the subtle has no origin.
The subtle roams within things, yet things cannot know it.
Thus it is said: "Virtue roams" refers to things.
The true person embodies the subtle and roams among things—this is subtle roaming.
Things attain the subtle, and the subtle resides within things—this is virtue roaming.
Things have decay, yet the subtle has no decay—thus it is said to return with things.

**Chapter Nine, Forty-Two Characters**

The subtle roams without obstruction, the origin roams without knowledge, the numinous roams without direction, the true roams without change, Dao roams without form, virtue roams without name, things roam without interval.
This is called roaming with things—here the Dao of life and death is exhausted.
Subtlety, origin, numinous, true, Dao—these five are names of Dao.
Yet only when there is roaming within these five is it called Dao.
Dao is my original true nature—it is called the beginning of the primordial origin.
Roaming in subtlety is without obstruction, roaming in origin is without knowledge, roaming in the numinous is without direction, roaming in the true is without change, roaming in Dao is without form.
Descending further to roam in virtue, it cannot be named by virtue.
Refining to roam among things, it cannot be bounded by things.
In its essence, roaming with the subtle, it cannot be seen.
In its coarseness, roaming with things, it cannot be concealed.
This is how the utmost person enters life and death, treating them as the constant alternation of morning and evening.

*Commentary on the Primordial Origin’s Precelestial Dao and Virtue, Scroll One—Concluded*
*Commentary on the Primordial Origin’s Precelestial Dao and Virtue, Scroll Two*
chunks.overlap_context: Dao is that when Dao descends to become things, its self remains unchanging—this is the spontaneity of Dao. What the world calls spontaneous is the self of things, such as the whiteness of swans or the blackness of crows. Lacking knowledge, they take black and white as the self of crows and swans, not knowing why swans are white or crows are black. There is also that which makes them so—this is not self. Since the world takes the non-self as self and the non-so as so, the sage avoids such terms.

chunks.original_text: 元篇一千言章 第一章一百五十九言 妙元元妙，神元元神，真元元真，道元元道，德元元德，元德复妙，与物返矣。 妙、元、神、真、道五者，各有浅深，乃学道者之分量。 此元之妙，非妙之妙。 此元之神，非妙之神。 此元之真，非妙之真。 此元之道，非妙之道。 此元之德，非妙之德。 众人自德散而为物，真人自德返而归妙，道与物返，物与道返，故曰顺之则为人，逆之则为道。 元非元，妙形之先。 形非形，混然而成。 妙元惚恍，忽然有象。 妙元恍惚，忽然有物。 物象杳冥，忽然有精。 精元含神，忽然有真。 非色之色，素朴含明，无状之状，无象之象。 元之所以为元者，非元也，乃妙形之始。 形之所以为形者，非形也，乃混然而成。 道自妙降而为元，始有恍惚之状，故曰妙元惚恍，忽然有象。 妙元恍惚，忽然有物。 物象出於杳冥之间，而有至精者存焉。 精全为神，神一为真，会真集神，为元之体。 故其体有明有色，有象有状，此色与明，状与象，具於吾之本始无作之者。 由有微心，吸撮尘象，尘集成根，遂丧本象，及与本明，至人迥脱根境，复还元明。 故见非色之色，素朴含明，无状之状，无象之象。 元之大象，寥廓幽光。 元和之鸣，元元独闻。 元象之形，元元独见。 元之象，非物之象，寥廓幽光，物不可得而窥，故元和之鸣，唯元独闻。 元象之形，唯元独见。 元元之元，真祖真母。 帝先道始，象之元纪。 吾始元元，元於元纪，复归吾始，吾不见吾。 始孰云吾元始，是谓始终，元纪之元。 妙不可见，至於元始有可见之渐，故以元之元为真祖真母。 帝先道始，有象之初，纪道至是，始露一发矣。 故吾始於元，渐有可纪之状。 虽渐可纪，复归於始。 吾且不知吾之始，而况於他哉。 是谓始终元纪之元。 言始终者，道在元方，有始之名。 物终则穷。 元纪之元，始於元，终於元，元元不穷。 无始无终是始终，元纪之元。 第二章一百十四言 元元胎光，九元之始，八卦之先，胎光始元，明明赫赫，恍恍惚惚，元元始光，妙生真有。 至人自妙出元，渐露光景。 人之三魂，一为胎光，故元元为胎光。 凡数自一至九而止，若十则复为一。 故大数止於九，九数皆起於元，故曰九元。 九元之始，则一也。 八卦之先，则乾坤为阴阳之祖，在易为太极，在乾亦为元，在人为胎光。 胎光始元，明明赫赫，恍恍惚惚，皆元之始光之谓也。 物自始光，即丧道本，故《佛书》谓之元明，故曰元明。 照生所，所立照，性亡若至人，则始於妙无，出为妙有，盖自妙而降，则粗道自元，而妙则神，此其所以不同。 故曰妙生真有。 元显元藏，黍珠中大象。 元起元没，黍珠中巨物。 元以大象，含万象。 元以巨物，吞万物。 物至於有形，则不能以大入细，以细藏大。 元本於性而未入於形，故可以显，可以隐，如人之梦魂游形中，而大地山河，无不有也。 人物徒役，无不彰也。 故若以形会，则两黍不能以相容。 若以性会，则黍珠中大象，不足以为怪矣。 盖由大象非象，故含万象。 巨物非物，故含万物。 圣人既论此理，又时显其迹，以觉方来。 欲以破形相之粗而昧者，但以神变目之甚者，又疑为诡幻。 此释氏所以薄世论而不近，良以此欤。
chunks.translated_text:
**Scroll Two, Chapter of One Thousand Words – First Section (159 characters)**

Subtle and origin intermingle, numinous and origin merge as one, true and origin unite, Dao and origin return to the source, virtue and origin revert to subtlety—thus do things return to their root.
Subtlety, origin, numinous, true, and Dao—each possesses depths and shallows, marking the measure of those who cultivate the Way.
This origin’s subtlety is not the subtlety of subtlety.
This origin’s numinous is not the numinous of subtlety.
This origin’s true is not the true of subtlety.
This origin’s Dao is not the Dao of subtlety.
This origin’s virtue is not the virtue of subtlety.
The multitude scatter their virtue and become things; the perfected person returns virtue to subtlety. Dao returns to things, things return to Dao—thus it is said: following it, one becomes human; reversing it, one attains Dao.

Origin is not origin—it precedes form.
Form is not form—it coalesces in undifferentiated oneness.
Subtle-origin is indistinct and vague, suddenly manifesting as image.
Subtle-origin is vague and indistinct, suddenly manifesting as thing.
Things and images emerge from profound obscurity, suddenly bearing essence.
Essence contains the numinous, the numinous unites as the true.
This is not the color of color—pristine simplicity holds luminosity.
This is not the form of form, not the image of image.
What makes origin *origin* is not origin—it is the beginning of subtle form.
What makes form *form* is not form—it coalesces in undifferentiated oneness.
Dao descends from subtlety to origin, first assuming indistinct and vague appearances. Thus it is said: subtle-origin is indistinct and vague, suddenly manifesting as image; subtle-origin is vague and indistinct, suddenly manifesting as thing.
Things and images arise from profound obscurity, yet within them abides the purest essence.
Essence gathers as the numinous, the numinous unites as the true—this is the essence of origin.
Thus its essence possesses luminosity and color, image and form. This color and luminosity, form and image, reside within our primordial, uncontrived nature.
Yet with the slightest stirring of the mind, one grasps at dust-like images. Dust accumulates into roots, and the original image and luminosity are lost.
The perfected person transcends the roots of perception and restores primordial luminosity.
Thus they perceive not the color of color—pristine simplicity holds luminosity; not the form of form, not the image of image.

The great image of origin is vast and boundless, its radiance profound.
The harmony of origin resounds—only origin alone hears it.
The form of origin’s image—only origin alone sees it.
The image of origin is not the image of things. Its vast and profound radiance cannot be glimpsed by things. Thus the harmony of origin is heard only by origin alone; the form of origin’s image is seen only by origin alone.

The origin of origin is the true ancestor, the true mother.
The emperor precedes the beginning of Dao; the origin is the primal record of images.
I begin with origin-origin, originating from the primal record, returning to my beginning—I do not see myself.
Who declares my origin as the primordial beginning? This is called the beginning and end, the origin of the primal record.
Subtlety cannot be seen, but in the primordial beginning, there are gradual signs of visibility. Thus the origin of origin is called the true ancestor, the true mother.
The emperor precedes the beginning of Dao; at the inception of images, the record of Dao first reveals a trace.
Thus I begin with origin, gradually assuming a recordable form.
Though gradually recordable, I return to the beginning.
I do not even know my own beginning—how much less others?
This is called the origin of the primal record of beginning and end.
To speak of beginning and end: Dao in its origin has the name of beginning.
Things end and are exhausted.
The origin of the primal record begins with origin and ends with origin—origin-origin is inexhaustible.
Without beginning or end—this is the origin of the primal record.

**Second Section (114 characters)**

Origin-origin is the womb-light, the beginning of the nine origins, preceding the eight trigrams.
Womb-light is the primal origin—bright, radiant, indistinct, vague.
Origin-origin’s primal light gives rise to true being.
The perfected person emerges from subtlety into origin, gradually revealing signs of light.
Of humanity’s three souls, one is womb-light—thus origin-origin is womb-light.
All numbers end at nine; ten reverts to one.
Thus the great number culminates at nine, and all nine numbers arise from origin—hence the nine origins.
The beginning of the nine origins is the one.
Preceding the eight trigrams, Qian and Kun are the ancestors of yin and yang. In the *Book of Changes*, this is the Supreme Ultimate; in Qian, it is origin; in humanity, it is womb-light.
Womb-light is the primal origin—bright, radiant, indistinct, vague—all referring to the primal light of origin.
Things, from their inception in light, lose the root of Dao. Thus Buddhist texts call it "primal luminosity"—hence *primal luminosity*.
Illuminating the place of arising, the place of arising establishes illumination. When nature perishes—if the perfected person begins with the subtlety of non-being and emerges into the subtlety of being, then from subtlety descending, the coarse Dao arises from origin, while subtlety remains numinous—this is their difference.
Thus it is said: subtlety gives birth to true being.

Origin reveals, origin conceals—the great image within the millet-pearl.
Origin arises, origin vanishes—the great thing within the millet-pearl.
Origin, through the great image, contains all images.
Origin, through the great thing, encompasses all things.
When things attain form, they cannot enter the minute with the vast or conceal the vast within the minute.
Origin, rooted in nature and not yet entering form, can reveal or conceal—like the dreaming soul wandering within the body, where mountains, rivers, and the great earth are all present, and all beings and affairs are manifest.
If one meets through form, two millets cannot contain each other.
If one meets through nature, the great image within the millet-pearl is no marvel.
For the great image is not image—thus it contains all images.
The great thing is not thing—thus it encompasses all things.
The sage, having expounded this principle, occasionally reveals its traces to awaken future generations.
They seek to dispel the ignorance of those who cling to coarse forms, yet when extraordinary transformations are witnessed, some dismiss them as deceptive illusions.
This is why the followers of the Buddha distance themselves from worldly discourse—is this not the reason?

chunks.original_text: 象中象，元非元，物中物，一非一。 象中象是元非元，物中物是一非一。 何以故。 元之妙能，使未至於元者，随元而化。 一之妙能，使未至於一者，同一而处。 此圣人既以成己，又以成物也。 大象藏於黍珠之中，大象未必尽元也。 彼虽未至於元，然以吾之元，而加彼之元，则彼亦以元化。 如李广之射虎，不知其为石，周处之斩蛟，不知其为水。 彼以一至之心，而石与水尚从而化，况吾之妙元而不可以化物哉。 故曰：元非元，一非一。 元象之元，含光自然，元元胎光，吾所谓象。 元元之始，含光自然。 释氏谓之觉明，道家谓之胎光。 释氏觉明谓之所，道家胎光谓之象。 性觉必明，明则亡所。 胎元必光，光为妙象。 妄为明觉所立，觉亡象而成形。 胎光光废佛，以觉明明而无所道，以胎光光而象妙。 妙象之象，觉明之明，是为道本。 物之真元，元母之先，道生道生，吾不能自生，吾元元之母。 物之真元，非元也。 唯本妙而后生元，故曰元母之先。 元母者，谓妙也。 及妙生元，元又降而生道。 申言道生者，言元生真，真生神，及神而后生道。 虽至於道，愈降而生物。 若原其生，则不然，竟非其自。 若推其自，必元元之母，妙之本始，然后能生物。 所谓妙者，乃本始如如不可得而生死者也。 第三章一百言 胎光元元，元元胎光，吾始元元，神视不见，神听不闻，神神不遇，神不可得。 故曰：不同，神而后知始。 胎光之始，莫见其眹，莫闻其音，各各自知，无相见者，故曰神神不遇。 是谓不同此之不同，物物如是。 然物不能为主宰者，以其神不全，而又为物转也。 方是之时，虽未有声色臭味之交，而六种识心已具於胎光元元之内。 至人以神为主，故六种识心不随根尘，俱以神化，为一精明。 众人神鉴不全，六种识心重者先受，既传一根，同根同染，转入生死，胎光益微。 故曰：神而后知始。 吾始於元元，无方妙天，吸光化妙。 元元吾始，妙母开户，乘光继元。 用在恍惚，道在绵绵。 孟子曰：尽其心者知其性，知其性则知天。 从孟子之说，是心之外有性，性之上有天。 《易》曰：穷理尽性，以至於命。 从《易》之说，是理之外有性，性之上有命。 孟子所谓天，即《易》之所谓命也。 古之达者，或以为见独，或以为无何有之乡，极世之语言，不过如此。 然所谓天果何方，所谓命者果何物耶。 至此《经》又谓之无方妙天，方胎光在元元之中，炳然独耀。 吾不知其处，亦不知其际，非无方妙天，而何根尘销落，吸光化妙，神用不测。 众妙所出，故谓之妙母开户，乘光继元。 万神自生，用在恍惚而不可执也。 道在绵绵而不可绝也。 非天下之至神，其孰能与於此哉。 无取无舍，无为自然，吾不知其自然。 元始元生，混然而成，妙极元得，元始自然。 元元之中，吸光化妙，混生万神，恍惚乘光，妙有开敷，亦不舍无而取有，亦不拾有而取无，悉皆无为自然之用。 亦不知其自，亦不知其然，混然而元成，妙极而元得。 故曰：元始自然之道，如是则妙，亦元元亦妙。 第四章一百二十六言 清浊交混，阴阳一元。 非清而清，元清生浊。 非浊而浊，元浊生清。 非阴元阴，非阳元阳，元道斯在，阴阳同生，清浊孰能名。
chunks.translated_text:
The image within image is not the primordial; the thing within thing is not the one.
The image within image is the primordial yet not the primordial; the thing within thing is the one yet not the one.
Why is this so?
The marvelous power of the primordial enables those not yet primordial to transform in accord with the primordial.
The marvelous power of the one enables those not yet one to dwell in unity.
This is how the sage perfects the self and, in turn, perfects all things.

The great image lies hidden within the millet-pearl, yet the great image is not necessarily wholly primordial.
Though it has not attained the primordial, when my primordial is applied to its primordial, it too transforms by the primordial.
Like Li Guang shooting the tiger, unaware it was stone; like Zhou Chu slaying the dragon, unaware it was water.
With a heart that has reached the one, even stone and water follow and transform—how much more can my marvelous primordial transform all things?
Thus it is said: the primordial is not the primordial; the one is not the one.

The primordial of the primordial image naturally contains radiance—what I call "image" is the primordial womb of radiance.
The inception of the primordial womb naturally contains radiance.
Buddhists call it *awakened luminosity*; Daoists call it *womb radiance*.
Buddhists’ *awakened luminosity* is termed "realm"; Daoists’ *womb radiance* is termed "image."
When inherent nature awakens, it must be luminous; when luminous, the realm vanishes.
When the primordial womb is radiant, radiance becomes the marvelous image.
Delusion establishes luminous awakening; awakening dissolves the image to form.
The womb radiance radiates the Buddha—awakened luminosity is luminous yet without realm; womb radiance is radiant yet the image is marvelous.
The image of the marvelous image, the luminosity of awakened luminosity—this is the root of the Dao.

The true primordial of things precedes the primordial mother.
The Dao begets the Dao—yet I cannot beget myself; I am the mother of the primordial primordial.
The true primordial of things is not the primordial.
Only when rooted in the marvelous does the primordial arise—thus it is said to precede the primordial mother.
The primordial mother is the marvelous.
When the marvelous begets the primordial, the primordial descends to beget the Dao.
To elaborate: the primordial begets the true; the true begets the numinous; only then does the Dao arise.
Though it reaches the Dao, it further descends to beget all things.
If one traces their arising, it is not so—nothing is self-generated.
If one traces their origin, it must be the mother of the primordial primordial, the inception of the marvelous—only then can they beget all things.
What is called the marvelous is the inception that is thus, thus, unattainable by birth and death.

**Chapter Three: One Hundred Words**
Womb radiance, primordial primordial—primordial primordial, womb radiance.
My inception is primordial primordial.
The spirit sees yet does not see; the spirit hears yet does not hear; the spirit meets the spirit yet does not meet; the spirit cannot be attained.
Thus it is said: only through the spirit can one know the inception.
At the inception of womb radiance, no trace is seen, no sound is heard.
Each knows for itself; none see one another—thus it is said the spirit meets the spirit yet does not meet.
This is called "not the same as this not-sameness"; all things are thus.
Yet things cannot be sovereign because their spirit is incomplete and is turned by things.
At this time, though the six senses have not yet engaged with sound, form, scent, or taste, the six kinds of perceptual consciousness already reside within the womb radiance of the primordial primordial.
The perfected one takes the spirit as sovereign, so the six kinds of perceptual consciousness do not follow the sense roots and dusts but are all transformed by the spirit into a single luminous clarity.
The multitude’s spirit-mirror is incomplete; the six kinds of perceptual consciousness, weighted, are first received.
Once transmitted to a sense root, they share the root’s defilement, sinking into birth and death, and the womb radiance grows faint.
Thus it is said: only through the spirit can one know the inception.

My inception is in the primordial primordial—boundless, marvelous heaven, inhaling radiance to transform into the marvelous.
The primordial primordial is my inception; the marvelous mother opens the gate, riding radiance to continue the primordial.
Its function lies in the indistinct; the Dao lies in the ceaseless.
Mencius said: "He who exhausts his heart knows his nature; knowing his nature, he knows Heaven."
According to Mencius, beyond the heart lies nature, and beyond nature lies Heaven.
The *Book of Changes* says: "Exhaust principle, fulfill nature, to reach destiny."
According to the *Changes*, beyond principle lies nature, and beyond nature lies destiny.
Mencius’ Heaven is the *Changes*’ destiny.
The enlightened of old sometimes called it *seeing the solitary*, sometimes *the land of nothing whatsoever*—the utmost of worldly speech goes no further.
Yet where is this Heaven? What is this destiny?
This *Scripture* calls it *boundless marvelous heaven*.
When womb radiance abides in the primordial primordial, it shines alone, resplendent.
I know not its place, nor its bounds—is this not boundless marvelous heaven?
When the sense roots and dusts dissolve, inhaling radiance transforms into the marvelous—spirit’s function is unfathomable.
The gateway of the myriad marvels opens; riding radiance, it continues the primordial.
The ten thousand spirits arise of themselves; its function lies in the indistinct, ungraspable.
The Dao lies in the ceaseless, unbroken.
Who but the most spiritually attuned under heaven could partake in this?

No grasping, no relinquishing—non-action, spontaneity.
I know not its spontaneity.
The primordial inception begets the primordial; all coalesces in undifferentiated oneness.
The marvelous reaches the primordial; the primordial inception is spontaneous.
Within the primordial primordial, inhaling radiance transforms into the marvelous.
The myriad spirits arise in undifferentiated oneness, riding radiance in the indistinct.
The marvelous unfolds—neither relinquishing the absent to grasp the present, nor discarding the present to grasp the absent.
All is the function of non-action and spontaneity.
I know not its self; I know not its thusness.
All coalesces to form the primordial; the marvelous reaches the primordial.
Thus it is said: the Dao of the primordial inception is spontaneous.
So it is marvelous—both the primordial primordial and the marvelous.

**Chapter Four: One Hundred Twenty-Six Words**
Clear and turbid intermingle; yin and yang are one primordial.
Not clear yet clear—the primordial clear begets the turbid.
Not turbid yet turbid—the primordial turbid begets the clear.
Not yin yet primordial yin; not yang yet primordial yang.
The primordial Dao abides here—yin and yang arise together; who can name clear and turbid?

For the great image is not image—thus it contains all images.
The great thing is not thing—thus it encompasses all things.
The sage, having expounded this principle, occasionally reveals its traces to awaken future generations.
They seek to dispel the ignorance of those who cling to coarse forms, yet when extraordinary transformations are witnessed, some dismiss them as deceptive illusions.
This is why the followers of the Buddha distance themselves from worldly discourse—is this not the reason?

chunks.original_text: 元清元浊，阴阳亦然。 元者，清浊始交，而未分阴阳，同为一元。 《易》曰：一阴一阳之谓道。 一阴一阳者，阴阳未分之谓也。 自阴阳未分，而继之以善。 自善而后，继之以性。 性立而后物成，世未有性未成而善先成者。 故《易》所谓道所谓善，皆物之先，非善恶之谓也。 方其清浊交混，阴阳同元，则非清非浊，非阴非阳，相交以性，而不交以形，故元清含浊，元浊含清，元阳含阴，元阴含阳，犹水火之不相射，清浊同源，阴阳同生，孰能名之哉。 妙象元象，妙声元声，声象不可得万物之根，万物之灵。 吾所谓一而非一，一而未彰。 吾所谓元而未元，元而未常。 妙象妙声，唯独听者可得而闻，独见者可得而视。 其声其象非象，人所可得见，所可得闻。 故为万物之根，万物之灵，方其为元也。 谓之数之始，一之祖。 然其实未彰，一犹未见。 谓之形之始，常之祖。 然其形未见，常犹未常。 圣人体之，谓之无名。 元一含妙，妙元流光。 流光含气，元妙之常。 吾曰元常之道，道法元常。 气、形、数，三者之在妙有。 非有非无，流光为气，气结为形，形见为数。 古之至人，体於妙无，出为妙有。 曷尝无是三者，然亦竟非有也。 盖流光之气，非阴阳所感。 妙气之形，非假合所造。 形见之数，非一二可求。 故入而为太虚，出而为妙有，分形散气形千万，不为有余。 敛景吸光形闭藏，不为不足。 是谓元妙之常，道法元常，故不可致诘。 第五章一百六十六言 阴阳之妙，清浊之杳，杳妙相因而元生。 阴阳同源之谓妙。 清浊相容之谓杳。 阴阳以气相同，清浊以形相混，妙气同为无气，妙形同为无形。 故曰杳妙相因。 元含万象，万象含元。 万象生元元，元元生万象。 元含万象，而非形也。 万象生於元，而非物也。 古之至人，反身而诚，则万物皆备於我。 致中和则位天地、育万物，皆在吾中和之中。 释氏谓意生身者，身随意生，非造所造。 即道家灵光八耀，混生万神，而如意所生，迅疾无碍，乃至种类俱生，无所不有，不可计数。 此之谓元元生万象。 神不知神，真不知真，道不知道。 吾元始於虚无，道隐无名，真隐无形，神隐无灵。 吾神爽灵，吾真幽精。 神隐无灵，无灵至神。 真隐无形，无形至真。 道隐无名，无名至道。 三无合元。 元之妙，神隐於无灵，真隐於无形，道隐於无名，故无灵为真神，无形於真真，无名为真道。 故曰三无即为元。 敷落五篇，非圣人强为之次也。 妙者，在道为圣之极，在人为魂之始。 非象非物，不死不生，吾之本始，所谓妙也。 元为妙之次，在人为胎光。 神为元之次，在人为爽灵。 真为神之次，在人为幽精。 自是以下，则为道。 自道以降，性成而形具，故人之三魂，一曰胎光，二曰爽灵，三曰幽精者，义取诸此。 《易》曰：精气为物，游魂为变。 精气为物，则质具而体成。 有成则有坏，物不足以为固，惟魂游於物，物坏而魂不亡。 故《易》谓之变。 古之圣人深切着明，所以示人者如此。 故妙在魂上，而道在魂下。 妙为魂之先，道为魂之降。 自道而降，圣人不居。 自道而上，众人不处。 众人所以生生死死，死死生生者，由道降为魄，魄盛而魂衰也。 圣人魂盛而魄亡，故与道同游。
chunks.translated_text:
**Primordial Clear and Primordial Turbid—so too are yin and yang.**
The Primordial is where clear and turbid first intermingle, yet yin and yang remain undivided, coalescing as one primordial unity. As the *Yi* says: "One yin, one yang—this is called the Dao." "One yin, one yang" refers precisely to the state before yin and yang separate. From this undivided yin-yang arises goodness; from goodness, then, arises nature. Only when nature is established do things take form. Never has there been a world where nature was unformed yet goodness already complete. Thus, what the *Yi* calls the Dao and what it calls goodness both precede things—they are not terms for good and evil.

When clear and turbid intermingle and yin and yang share a single primordial source, they are neither clear nor turbid, neither yin nor yang. They merge through nature, not through form. Thus, primordial clear contains turbid; primordial turbid contains clear; primordial yang contains yin; primordial yin contains yang—like water and fire that do not repel each other. Clear and turbid share a single source; yin and yang arise together. Who can name them?

Marvelous images and primordial images, marvelous sounds and primordial sounds—sounds and images cannot encompass the root of the myriad things, the spirit of the myriad things. What I call "one" is not one, yet one remains unmanifest. What I call "primordial" is not yet primordial, yet the primordial is not yet constant. Marvelous images and marvelous sounds—only the solitary listener may hear them; only the solitary seer may see them. Their sounds and images are not images—what people may see or hear. Thus they are the root of the myriad things, the spirit of the myriad things, for in their primordial state they are called the beginning of numbers, the ancestor of the One. Yet in truth, they remain unmanifest; the One is not yet visible. They are called the beginning of form, the ancestor of constancy. Yet their form is unseen, and constancy is not yet constant.

The sage embodies this and calls it the Nameless. The Primordial One contains the marvelous; the marvelous Primordial flows with radiance. Flowing radiance contains qi; this is the constancy of the Primordial Marvelous. I say: the Dao of primordial constancy models itself on primordial constancy.

Qi, form, and number—these three reside within marvelous being. They are neither being nor non-being. Flowing radiance becomes qi; qi congeals into form; form appears as number. The perfected ones of antiquity embodied marvelous non-being and emerged as marvelous being. How could these three ever be absent? Yet in the end, they are not being. For the qi of flowing radiance is not stirred by yin and yang; the form of marvelous qi is not fabricated by artificial combination; the number revealed in form cannot be sought in one or two.

Thus, entering, it becomes the Great Void; emerging, it becomes marvelous being. Dispersing form and scattering qi into a thousand myriad shapes does not make it excessive. Gathering its luminous trace and absorbing its radiance, closing and concealing its form, does not make it deficient. This is called the constancy of the Primordial Marvelous. The Dao models itself on primordial constancy—thus it cannot be questioned.

**Chapter Five: One Hundred Sixty-Six Words**

The marvelousness of yin and yang, the profundity of clear and turbid—profound and marvelous give rise to the Primordial through mutual dependence. Yin and yang sharing a single source is called the marvelous; clear and turbid containing each other is called the profound. Yin and yang unite through qi; clear and turbid merge through form. Marvelous qi is as if without qi; marvelous form is as if without form. Thus it is said: the profound and the marvelous give rise to one another.

The Primordial contains the myriad images; the myriad images contain the Primordial. The myriad images give birth to the Primordial Primordial; the Primordial Primordial gives birth to the myriad images. The Primordial contains the myriad images, yet it is not form. The myriad images arise from the Primordial, yet they are not things.

The perfected ones of antiquity turned inward and attained sincerity—then the myriad things were all complete within them. By attaining the Center and Harmony, they stood with Heaven and Earth and nurtured the myriad things, all within their own Center and Harmony. The Buddhists speak of the "mind-made body"—the body arises following the mind, not through artificial fabrication. This is like the Daoists' "eight radiant luminances of the spirit-light," where the myriad spirits intermingle and arise as the mind wills, swift and unhindered, even to the point of generating entire species, with nothing lacking and beyond reckoning. This is what is meant by the Primordial Primordial giving birth to the myriad images.

The spirit does not know the spirit; the true does not know the true; the Dao does not know the Dao. I originate from the Void and Non-being. The Dao is hidden, without name; the true is hidden, without form; the spirit is hidden, without numinosity. My spirit is luminous and numinous; my true is profound and refined. The spirit is hidden, without numinosity—yet without numinosity, it attains the utmost spirit. The true is hidden, without form—yet without form, it attains the utmost true. The Dao is hidden, without name—yet without name, it attains the utmost Dao. The Three Absences merge into the Primordial.

The marvelousness of the Primordial lies in the spirit hidden without numinosity, the true hidden without form, the Dao hidden without name. Thus, without numinosity is the true spirit; without form is the true true; without name is the true Dao. Therefore, it is said: the Three Absences are the Primordial.

The unfolding of these five chapters is not an arbitrary ordering by the sage. The marvelous, in the Dao, is the ultimate of sageliness; in humans, it is the beginning of the hun-soul. It is neither image nor thing, neither dying nor living—this is my original beginning, what is called the marvelous. The Primordial follows the marvelous; in humans, it is the fetal radiance. The spirit follows the Primordial; in humans, it is the luminous numen. The true follows the spirit; in humans, it is the profound essence.

Below this lies the Dao. From the Dao downward, nature is formed and shape is complete. Thus, the three hun-souls of humans—first, the fetal radiance; second, the luminous numen; third, the profound essence—derive their meaning from this. As the *Yi* says: "Essence-qi becomes things; the wandering hun-soul becomes transformation." When essence-qi becomes things, substance is complete and the body is formed. With formation comes decay; things cannot be enduring. Only the hun-soul wanders among things—when things decay, the hun-soul does not perish. Thus the *Yi* calls it transformation.

The sages of antiquity deeply and clearly expounded this to instruct people. Thus, the marvelous lies above the hun-soul, while the Dao lies below it. The marvelous precedes the hun-soul; the Dao descends from it. Below the Dao, the sage does not dwell. Above the Dao, the multitude does not reside.

The reason the multitude is born and dies, dies and is born, is that the Dao descends into the po-soul, and when the po-soul flourishes, the hun-soul wanes. The sage’s hun-soul flourishes while the po-soul vanishes—thus they wander together with the Dao.

chunks.original_text: 众人魄盛而魂亡，故与物俱坏。 由是观之，所谓三魂者，即此元神真。 而七魄者，喜怒哀惧爱恶欲也。 全魂即为仙，全魄则为鬼。 魂与魄两立，则为人。 此理之自然，圣人复起不易吾言矣。 虽然圣人为魂，众人为魄，此自其既成而言之，若元始之初，魂魄未分，清浊且未之判，则孰为魂，孰为魄哉。 及其既分，全则为魂，散则为魄，（氵＋公）而上则为魂，流而下则为魄，正则为魂，邪则为魄，真则为魂，伪则为魄，其本同，其末异，故魄亦魂也，魂亦魄也。 魄消则为魂，魂消则为魄。 佛氏所谓无明即佛性者，此之谓欤。 吾元始之元道，周旋不可妙，妙不可得。 自然元妙，上下往来，周旋自然，吾始於元元之元。 吾不知其自然元道元德，孰能体吾元道元德，复归吾元始，是谓还元返本之道尽矣。 圣人体元始之道，以周旋於物，妙藏於形迹之间，和其光，同其尘，不可以妙非，不可以妙谓，在其形迹之间，而形迹亦妙，故妙不可得。 上下往来，周旋世故，自然元妙，而不见其徼。 盖吾本始於元之元体，吾自然以应於物，而吾亦不知其自然。 如是则不独元道化妙，而元德亦化妙。 巨细心迹，无不妙者，孰能知之哉。 由吾虽体道德而出世，复返道德於元始，是谓还元返本之道尽矣。 第六章一百四十八言 元生神，神生元。 元之降为神，神之合为元。 神以元而灵，元以神而显。 故上下相生。 吾元自粹，元一旋生，元色未辟，恍惚杳冥。 苍素彤黅舍四象，四象含光。 苍素彤黅，为四象不言玄者。 玄为色之母，无色为玄。 元色未辟，其光玄玄。 元一者，玄之谓也。 由有元一旋生五元，故天一为水。 天生水中，水浮天而载地。 元之未辟，自然太玄之中，有苍素彤黅之光，合为四象五元，恍惚杳冥。 吾元始之妙，用一元，非一元，一元之妙。 妙生元，元生妙。 妙为元之祖，元为妙之用。 自妙入元，故称一元。 一元之用，元妙交相生，不知妙之为元，元之为妙。 苍素隐显，左右相元。 元光恍惚，元出元入，出入无门，吾不知其元。 元彤上下，不皦不昧，上下一元，元法自然。 苍，东方木色之气。 素，西方金色之气。 木左金右，故曰左右相元。 彤，南方火色之气。 元，北方玄色之气。 火上水下，故曰元彤上下。 元光恍惚，东西苍素，有出有入，而不见其门。 南北玄彤，有上有下，而不显其晦。 有出入而不见其出入，有显晦而不见其显晦，故神用无门，道法自然。 无为自然，自然无为，道在恍惚之先，元元无为之先，孰能体吾无为自然。 元因无为，无为因元，因元生自然，吾不知其然。 吾元始无为之天。 无为之天，有苍而非木，有素而非金，有彤而非火，有玄而非水，有黅而非土。 有左有右，而非左非右。 有上有下，而非上非下。

The multitude’s po-soul flourishes while the hun-soul perishes—thus they perish together with things. From this perspective, the so-called "three hun-souls" are precisely this primordial spirit, true and authentic. The "seven po-souls" are joy, anger, sorrow, fear, love, aversion, and desire. When the hun-soul is whole, one becomes an immortal; when the po-soul is whole, one becomes a ghost. When hun-soul and po-soul stand in balance, one becomes human. This is the natural principle, and even if the sages were to rise again, they would not alter my words.

Though the sage embodies the hun-soul and the multitude embodies the po-soul, this is spoken of only after their formation. As for the primordial beginning, when hun-soul and po-soul were undivided and the clear and turbid had not yet separated, who could distinguish which was hun and which was po? Once divided, wholeness becomes hun, dispersion becomes po; ascent becomes hun, descent becomes po; uprightness becomes hun, perversion becomes po; truth becomes hun, falsehood becomes po. Their root is the same, but their ends differ—thus the po-soul is also the hun-soul, and the hun-soul is also the po-soul. When the po-soul dissolves, it becomes hun; when the hun-soul dissolves, it becomes po. What the Buddhists call "ignorance is Buddha-nature" refers precisely to this.

My primordial Dao of the primordial beginning revolves in ineffable mystery, yet this mystery cannot be grasped. Naturally primordial and wondrous, it ascends and descends, revolving of itself—I begin from the primordial of the primordial. I know not its natural primordial Dao and primordial virtue. Who can embody my primordial Dao and primordial virtue, returning to my primordial beginning? This is the Way of returning to the origin and reverting to the root, fully realized.

The sage embodies the Dao of the primordial beginning, revolving among things, concealing marvelousness within form and traces. Harmonizing its light, blending with the dust, it cannot be said to lack marvelousness, nor can marvelousness be ascribed to it. It dwells within form and traces, yet even form and traces are marvelous—thus its marvelousness cannot be grasped. Ascending and descending, revolving through worldly affairs, naturally primordial and wondrous, yet its subtlety is unseen. For my original essence is the primordial body of the primordial beginning, and I respond naturally to things, yet I know not this naturalness. Thus not only does the primordial Dao transform into marvelousness, but primordial virtue also transforms into marvelousness. From the vast to the minute, from the heart to its traces, all is marvelous—who can comprehend it? Therefore, though I embody the Dao and virtue to transcend the world, I return them to the primordial beginning. This is the Way of returning to the origin and reverting to the root, fully realized.

**Chapter Six (One Hundred Forty-Eight Characters)**

The primordial generates spirit; spirit generates the primordial.
The primordial descends to become spirit; spirit unites to become the primordial.
Spirit is numinous through the primordial; the primordial is manifest through spirit.
Thus above and below generate one another.

My primordial essence is pure; the primordial One revolves and generates. Before primordial colors unfold, there is only dim obscurity. Azure, white, vermilion, and yellow-green contain the four images, and the four images hold light. Azure, white, vermilion, and yellow-green form the four images—here, the profound is not spoken of. The profound is the mother of colors; colorlessness is the profound. Before primordial colors unfold, their light is profoundly dark. The primordial One is what is called the profound.

From the primordial One revolving, the five primordials are born—thus Heaven’s One becomes water. Heaven generates water within, water floats Heaven and bears Earth. Before the primordial unfolds, within the great profound, there naturally exists the light of azure, white, vermilion, and yellow-green, uniting to form the four images and five primordials in dim obscurity.

My marvelousness of the primordial beginning employs the primordial One, yet is not the primordial One—it is the marvelousness of the primordial One. Marvelousness generates the primordial; the primordial generates marvelousness. Marvelousness is the ancestor of the primordial; the primordial is the function of marvelousness. From marvelousness entering the primordial, it is called the primordial One. The function of the primordial One is the mutual generation of primordial and marvelousness—one knows not marvelousness as primordial, nor primordial as marvelousness.

Azure and white alternate in concealment and revelation, left and right mutually primordial. Primordial light is dim and obscure; the primordial emerges and enters, emerging and entering without gate—I know not its primordial. Vermilion and profound ascend and descend, neither bright nor dark. Above and below are one primordial, the primordial following nature.

Azure is the qi-color of wood in the East; white is the qi-color of metal in the West. Wood is left, metal is right—thus it is said left and right are mutually primordial. Vermilion is the qi-color of fire in the South; profound is the qi-color of water in the North. Fire ascends, water descends—thus it is said vermilion and profound ascend and descend. Primordial light is dim and obscure; in the East and West, azure and white emerge and enter, yet their gate is unseen. In the South and North, profound and vermilion ascend and descend, yet their brightness and obscurity are unapparent. There is emergence and entry without visible emergence or entry, brightness and obscurity without visible brightness or obscurity—thus the spirit’s function has no gate, and the Dao follows nature.

Non-action is natural; naturalness is non-action. The Dao precedes dim obscurity; the primordial precedes primordial non-action—who can embody my non-action and naturalness? The primordial arises from non-action; non-action arises from the primordial. From the primordial, naturalness is born—I know not how this is so.

My primordial beginning is the Heaven of non-action. In the Heaven of non-action, there is azure yet not wood, white yet not metal, vermilion yet not fire, profound yet not water, yellow-green yet not earth. There is left and right, yet neither left nor right; there is above and below, yet neither above nor below.

chunks.original_text: 有出有入，而非出非入。 有显有晦，而非显非晦。 有色非色，有象非象，自然非自然，无为非无为，故曰：孰能体吾无为自然。 又曰：元生自然，吾不知其然。 是之谓无为之天。 第七章二十言 有无上下，左右内外，恍惚杳冥，妙妙中间，元在其中。 物必有有无之数，上下之位，左右之别，内外之界。 物之所不能免妙，妙之中元在其间。 非有非无，非上非下，非左非右，非内非外，恍惚杳冥，未涉此八者。 第八章一百五十言 元黄始妙，始妙相因。 元因黄，黄因元，元始黄始，不知其以。 以道言曰元，以色言曰玄。 故元亦玄也。 天元地黄，皆因始妙之本。 元因黄，黄因元，交相因，交相生，元始黄始，不知其以，所谓以者妙之所也。 不见之色，不闻之声，妙之又妙，忽然而生。 无象之象，无物之状，妙之又妙，忽然而形。 元元见矣。 赤素变化，幽黄洞彰，元常造作，元道由生。 吾不知其生，无为元黄，妙更之根。 声色生於至妙，物象成於至妙，忽然而生，忽然而成，无使之者，故赤素变化，火金相克而相成。 幽黄洞彰，水土同处而相克。 是为元常造化。 元黄之道，为万化更变之根。 根生至妙，妙生元，元生黄，黄生元，三一之妙，自然而成。 至人根於至妙，妙生元，元生黄，黄复生元，自无入有，自有化无，妙元黄三而一，一而三。 故曰三一之妙，自然而成。 元元又元，中有元黄之道。 元始元元之母，元声元象。 吾元元之母，声象得矣。 吾曰此元元，吾不知其元元，道无上。 元中有色，故曰元黄。 元元之母，出生色象，故色象以元为母。 元元以吾为母。 唯吾无母，是谓吾不知其元元。 道无上。 第九章一十六言 妙隐元生，道隐妙有，有无相生，神用不穷。 妙隐而元始生，元含至妙道隐，而物始有道，妙有中。 妙中之元，元非显也。 有中之道，道非隐也。 故元亦妙，有亦妙，有无相生，神用不穷。 元始说先天道德经注解卷之二竟 元始说先天道德经注解卷之三 神篇一千言章 第－章二百五十二言

There is emergence and entry, yet neither emergence nor entry. There is brightness and obscurity, yet neither brightness nor obscurity. There is color yet no color, form yet no form, naturalness yet no naturalness, non-action yet no non-action—thus it is said: who can embody my non-action and naturalness? It is also said: the primordial gives birth to naturalness, yet I know not how this is so. This is called the Heaven of non-action.

**Chapter Seven: Twenty Words**
There is being and non-being, above and below, left and right, inner and outer, dim obscurity and profound darkness—within the wondrous midst, the primordial resides therein. All things must possess the reckoning of being and non-being, the positions of above and below, the distinctions of left and right, the boundaries of inner and outer. What things cannot escape is the wondrous; within the wondrous, the primordial abides in their midst. It is neither being nor non-being, neither above nor below, neither left nor right, neither inner nor outer—dim and obscure, profound and dark, untouched by these eight.

**Chapter Eight: One Hundred Fifty Words**
The primordial and the yellow begin in the wondrous; the wondrous arises from their mutual dependence. The primordial depends on the yellow, the yellow depends on the primordial; the primordial begins with the yellow, the yellow begins with the primordial—I know not their origin. In terms of the Dao, it is called the primordial; in terms of color, it is called the profound. Thus, the primordial is also the profound. The primordial of Heaven and the yellow of Earth both depend on the root of the wondrous beginning. The primordial depends on the yellow, the yellow depends on the primordial; they mutually depend, mutually give rise—primordial beginning and yellow beginning, I know not their origin, for what is called "origin" is the abode of the wondrous. The color unseen, the sound unheard, wondrous beyond the wondrous, suddenly arising. The form without form, the shape without substance, wondrous beyond the wondrous, suddenly taking shape. The primordial is manifest.

Vermilion and white transform, dark and yellow intermingle—constantly the primordial creates, and from the primordial Dao, life arises. I know not its arising; non-action is the root of the primordial and the yellow, the foundation of wondrous change. Sound and color arise from utmost wondrousness; things and forms take shape from utmost wondrousness—suddenly arising, suddenly forming, with no agent to cause it. Thus, vermilion and white transform, fire and metal overcome yet complete each other. Dark and yellow intermingle, water and earth coexist yet overcome each other. This is the constant creation of the primordial. The Dao of the primordial and the yellow is the root of all transformations and changes. The root gives birth to utmost wondrousness; wondrousness gives birth to the primordial, the primordial gives birth to the yellow, the yellow gives birth to the primordial—the wondrousness of the Three-in-One forms naturally.

The perfected one roots in utmost wondrousness; wondrousness gives birth to the primordial, the primordial gives birth to the yellow, the yellow again gives birth to the primordial—from non-being to being, from being to non-being, the wondrous, primordial, and yellow are three yet one, one yet three. Thus it is said: the wondrousness of the Three-in-One forms naturally. The primordial again primordial—within it lies the Dao of the primordial and the yellow. The primordial is the mother of the primordial; primordial sound, primordial form. My primordial is the mother—sound and form are attained. I call this the primordial primordial, yet I know not its primordial primordial, for the Dao is without superior.

Within the primordial there is color, thus it is called the primordial yellow. The mother of the primordial primordial gives birth to color and form; thus, color and form take the primordial as their mother. The primordial primordial takes me as its mother. Only I have no mother—this is called my not knowing its primordial primordial. The Dao is without superior.

**Chapter Nine: Sixteen Words**
The wondrous conceals the primordial’s arising; the Dao conceals the wondrous being. Being and non-being give rise to each other; the spirit’s function is inexhaustible. The wondrous conceals, and the primordial begins to arise; the primordial contains utmost wondrousness. The Dao conceals, and things begin to possess the Dao within wondrous being. Within the wondrous midst, the primordial—yet the primordial is not manifest. Within being, the Dao—yet the Dao is not concealed. Thus, the primordial is also wondrous, being is also wondrous; being and non-being give rise to each other, and the spirit’s function is inexhaustible.

chunks.original_text: 元中有神，神之又神，吾不知其神。 神中有元，元之又元，吾不知其元。 元神和合，道法自然，吾不知其自然。 元神真道，皆从妙出。 五而一，一而五，故元中有神，神中有元。 方其为神也，不自知其神。 方其为元也，不自知其元。 元神和合，亦且不知其和合。 故虽自然，亦且不知其然。 左动右应，右动左应，呼之出之，吸之入之，远之又远，一之又一，神用神，一用一，吾不知其用，吾曰无为。 吾非无为，本不知其用。 应之者静，神之道。 道无所不在，充满六合，包含虚空。 苟执其机，则无所不应。 如抚宫宫动，抚角角起，盖有不知其然而然者，故左动则右应，右动则左应，呼而出之，还复吸之，吸而入之，还复呼之，以为近耶，远之又远，以为多耶，一之又一，是之谓神。 虽全於神，吾且不知其用。 使神用神，神神更用，则神不知神。 使一用一，一一更用，则一不知一。 如汞走盘中，一一自圆，无使之者，故吾曰无为。 如此则虽无为非无我，我不知其用。 应之者静，是谓神之道。 妙元生神，吾不知之生。 吾所谓至生。 至妙生妙，妙由妙生，自生之道。 吾元言於妙生不可穷，无复得其始，吾能知其已。 自妙元降而生神，吾不知神之生，盖守妙体元神神自生。 吾不知其生，是谓至生。 至生者，神生於妙，生不可穷。 既不可穷，则无得其始。 无得其始，则不见其已。 虽不见已，至妙施而寂还，归於妙有，若已者非实已也。 吾能知其已，既知其已，可复使之起矣。 左动左应，吾不在左。 右动右应，吾不在右。 呼之出之，吾不在外。 吸之入之，吾不在内。 吾始从而应之，已失吾矣。 吾所应运守乎大方之本，故无方。 吾所应变立乎大象之首，故无体。 左动左应而吾不在左，右动右应而吾不在右。 则动非我，应亦非我。 呼而出之，不知有我之出。 吸而入之，不知有我之入。 盖我无所不在。 《楞严》所谓性空真火，周遍法界，譬如手执阳燧，求火於日，一处执镜，一处火生，遍世界执，遍世界起。 人固知其有左有右，有呼有吸，而不知无所不在，殆将无应无动，无出无入，若纤毫有应之之心，则役於物之不暇，又安知吾之为吾哉。 唯吾守乎大方以应运，故其运无方。 吾唯立乎无象以应变，故其象无体。 外无方，内无体，非天下至神，其孰能与於此哉。 吾常变化，吾不知其变化。 吾始一於元中，吾方三化至真。 与吾为一，一非一，吾用与不用，吾不知其动静，神之又神。 神之生於元妙之中，如云出山，须臾之间，变态横生，而云未尝自知也。 吾体於妙，一化於元，再化於神，三化於真。 虽三化而未尝不一，一亦三，三亦一，用与不用，无不皆化。 故动亦神，静亦神，神之又神。 第二章三十三言 妙元神一七九三，阴阳天地日月，土木火金水。 一二三，一二三，一二三，神在无无之元。 妙至元涉於象，至神涉於数，故元篇言苍素彤黅之象，神篇言一七九三之数。 揆之河图，则一为下，九为上，三为左，七为右。 验之天数，则始青得九阳为木，丹光得三阳为火，素灵得七阳为金，玄上得一阳为水，皆一七九三之数，分布於四方。 在阴阳为气数，在天地为运数，在日月为交数，在五行为用数。 庄子曰：道与一为二，二与一为三，自此以往，巧历不能知其数，夫自无适有而至於三，而况自有适有乎。
